Forum Post: 
Post title: New rating option idea
Post description: I think there should be an option to be able to add a discussion, but no reply . By setting the prefs like that, and allowing for Ratings , students would be able to begin their forum experience by posting a "discussion" and then rating his/her peers' discussions without having the distracting option of a reply also. Our first forum exercise (just to understand what it is all about) is to post an idea to improve the school. When they are done posting their idea, they are to rate other students' ideas with "I totally agree" down to "I totally don't agree," with gradations between. This activity is to teach them how to do ratings. I've found replies allowed along with the ratings link confuses some of my new Moodle students (all of whom are 12 years old or younger). They lose track what they are looking at. This idea would not eliminate any current options, but would add an additional new option.

Post title: How to grade forum postings on quality and quantity?
Post description: We use a rubric to rate the quality of posts, and we usually also require a certain number of posts for each discussion. Does anyone else use both quality and quantity to assess forum participation? If so, how do you set it up for grading? In 1.8.x, our instructors could export the gradebook to Excel at the end of each discussion and see all the ratings (from our custom scale) in the spreadsheet cell for that assignment. Thus, instructors could quickly see if students had made the minimum number of postings and average the scores to enter into an offline assignment called "Weekly Forum Grade." In 1.9.x, exporting the gradebook to an Excel file will only produce one number that is an aggregate based on the settings for that forum. The only way I can see to grade on both quality and quantity is to let Moodle average the ratings and then go to every participants activity report to be sure they made the minimum number of postings. Or, maybe the participants report could show the number of postings for all the students in one report? I would appreciate any insight. I cannot upgrade to 1.9.x until I have a good plan for assessing forums. I know that this question is a blend of forum and gradebook, but I thought it was a better fit here. Thank you, Bruce

Post title: New Functionalites: additional forumtype "metaforum" and enhanced linking between forums and resources
Post description: Hallo everybody, as promised I implemented two new features for Moodle within the scope of my diploma thesis. 1. A new forumtype: Metaforum A metaforum is now an additional forumtype. Metaforums offer a view on chosen forums of the same course and don't contain posts themselves. This forumtype should be helpfull to keep track of new posts etc. if a lot of forums exist in one course. Metaforums can be used to give a summarized overview of chosen forums. 2. Enhanced linking between forums and resources Generally spoken this is a possibility to allocated discussions to resources of the same course. To admit this resources can now optionally be allocated to forums. If such allocations have been made, discussions in forums can be allocated to one of the resources allocated to the forum. If an allocation has been made while viewing a resource a link to add a new discussion allocated to the resource viewed is displayed. If discussions have already been allocated a link to an overview of all allocated discussions is displayed too. I would be glad about testers and comments on the new features. Of course I'd like to answer further questions too. Enclosed you find installation bundles and directions for Moodle 1.6.1 to install either one of the new functions or both new functions.

Post title: Q&A Forum Instructions
Post description: Hello, I work at the University of Illinois to create Moodle courses for our instructors and help them understand how to use Moodle. Many of our instructors had questions on how to set up a Q&A Forum on Moodle 1.9.9. When we directed our instructors to moodle.org for help, they still had questions on how to set it up. I want to get your opinion. I posted the instructions that we came up with below. Are these instructions helpful? Is there anywhere else we could direct the instructors for help? Thanks! Q and A Forum Help Article The Q and A Forum is a great instructional tool for instructors to require students to respond to a question or prompt before reading what their peers think. This kind of activity works well to foster original thinking while reducing the âme tooâ posts that can be common in discussion forums. Unfortunately, the default settings for the Q and A Forum need to be modified for it to function as intended. In most cases when using a Q and A Forum, an instructor should be the only user starting new threads (discussion topics). Students will then respond to the instructorâs threads and then they will be able to view and respond to their peersâ posts. When setting up a Q and A Forum, instructors should not include the discussion questions, and/or prompts to which your students should respond in the Forum introduction. The Forum introduction is the place to inform students that they should respond to each of the discussion threads first before being able to view and respond their peersâ posts. The threads posted by the instructor should be the discussion questions and/or prompts to which the students should respond. A Q and A Forum should always have at least one thread started by the instructor before students access it. To configure the Q and A Forum to work as described above, make the following changes: Create a Q and A Forum and add a general Forum Introduction. Access the Override permissions tab. Select the Student role. Set the Start new discussions permission to prevent. Save the changes. Save the forum. Add a new question or prompt for your students to reply to before seeing their peersâ responses. Add as many new questions or prompts as desired for this Q and A Forum activity.

To remove the "Add a new discussion" link on the students' pages, you'll assign a No New Threads role to your students. How to do it?

Post title: Forum discussion thread subscription behaviour - just checkin
Post description: Hi folks, I love the new ability to subscribe directly to discussion threads, but just wanted to check the following. With forum subscription set to Auto-subscription, participants start out being subscribed to all discussion threads, and can opt-out if they want. Â This is the behaviour I expect, and seems to work. With forum subscription set to Optional subscription, Moodle *should* check back with the participant's User profile preferences. Â If the preference is not to be subscribed, the participant should not be subscribed to any forum threads. Â If the preference is to be subscribed, then participants shouldÂ start out being subscribed to all discussion threads, and can opt-out if they want. Â Except that the behaviour I'm seeing on my Moodle 2.8.3+ (Build: 20150212) site is that regardless of preference, participants start out subscribed to all threads, and can opt-out. Â Making optional subscription mode no different to auto-subscription mode. Is this intentional? Â Have I misunderstood something? All the best, Lindy (@moodlechick)
Comments associated with the post: 
Comment 1: Hi Lindy, So with auto-subscription, yes. Students start out subscribed to all discussions but can opt-out of either forum subscription, or per-discussion subscription as the choose. With optional subscription, Moodle does not subscribe them by default at all. This has never been the case. The profile setting determines the default setting when a user replies to a discussion. That's to say that when a forum is in Optional subscription, and replies to a discussion they have not taken part in before, this is where the profile preference comes in. It either defaults to subscribing them to the discussion, or remaining unsubscribed. So there should be a difference between Optional and Automatic subscription. However , if you take an existing forum and change it from Automatic to Optional then the existing subscriptions will remain in place until a user unsubscribes. Any new user will not be subscribed. Just to be clear, when you create and Automatic forum, under the hood it subscribes every user in the course to that forum and they gain a subscription setting. Hope that clarifies things, Andrew
Comment 2: Thanks very much Andrew, clarified beautifully. Â I think I may have found a bug on my site, but will keep testing, and raise a tracker issue of that's the case. Appreciate how quickly you responded too! Cheers, Lindy
Comment 3: Hi Andrew, do may know some administrator settings that I can use to have: - autosubscription in a forum (so users are subscribed by the trainers) - notifications send out to participants only to new discussion topics and not for the replies? I fear the notification only to new discussion is something that has to be managed by the single user.

Comments associated with the post: 
Comment 1: There is one main administrator who is created when the Moodle is set up; after that you can have a many(or preferably as few) administrators as possible. Admins can do anything on the site. You won't need to alter your database; you can import the users and decide in advance who you want in charge of the Moodle and who you just want to be able to create forums/chat etc. If courses are set up in advance you can make your users teachers if you want them all to be able to create forums and so on. A teacher does not have admin rights over the whole site (and therefore cannot 'break it' if that's what you're worried about)

Post title: Moodle
Post description: What is the purpose of Moodle?
Comments associated with the post: 
Comment 1: This question is in the wrong forum, perhaps you might be better off asking a Moderator to move it to Comparisons and Advocacy. You will get a more comprehensive answer there, I suspect. The intent of Moodle is to provide a consistent platform for "Learners" to engage in education, training or any intellectual development. A learner can be anyone who is able to use a computer and wants to expand their practical and/or theoretical skills base. The practicality of Moodle is that it provides a consistent platform for "Instructors" to develop resources and activities for Learners to engage with to allow them to expand their practical and/or theoretical skills base. The benefit of Moodle is that it is a mode of communications between Learners and Instructors in a variety of ways which ultimately allows both Learners and Instructors to improve their practical and intellectual abilities by delivering opportunities for the development of a body of work demonstrating those skills and abilities. Post title: Students can't reply to teacher-generated thread
Post description: Hi everyone, We're just starting with Moodle here. I've got a teacher who has created a general forum in her class and has it set so that students can create discussions and reply. Comment 1: Hi there, Having the same problem here, and changing settings in the particular forum doesn't seem to have any effect...
Comment 2: Check the group settings for the course as a whole and for that particular forum. I seem to recall that we had a similar issue with a forum and tinkering with the group settings resolved it.
Comment 3: Thank you Tony! Changing the group setting for the course to "no groups", and forcing it seems to do the trick all right...but it does seem strange. Thanks again.
Comment 4: Glad it helped!
Comment 5: I AM HAVING THIS PROBLEM I have done everything and have posted this in another post. I even deleted the groupsÂ  and just have students and NO ONE can post replies to my postsÂ  and even other STUDENTSÂ  cant reply to THEIR OWN POSTS
Comment 6: I'm also having this problem. There are no 'Reply' links for studentsÂ in my forums. Adjusting the Group settings in both the course and the forum doesn't fix the problem, e.g. selecting 'No groups' and enforcing. Can anyone help?
Comment 7: Are you using a News Forum?Â  I could be wrong, but I seem to remember that at one point I used a News Forum for a discussion and students could not reply.

Comment 9: If your forum is set up for separate groups or visible groups, when the teacher posts a thread they have to select which group their post is going to. Comment 10: Many Thanks Bruce, You hit the nail on the head. You might be embarassed but not as embarrassed as me for taking so long and not realising.
Comment 11: I got the final solution!!! You need to chechk the attributs of you roles. Edit the Student Role (for the hole site as admin, in User >> Permission >> Define Roles) and set the attribute "Reply to News" in the fourum section to allow. Comment 13: I had the same problem. In the Course settings I had set the Group Mode to Visible and Force to YES. Then I went back to the forum I was having problems with and change the Group mode to No Groups and the problem was solved.

Post title: What's wrong with the Sakai UI (and Moodle's as well)
Post description: I would like to call your attention to the following blog post http://mfeldstein.com/index.php/weblog/permalink/whats_wrong_with_the_sakai_user_interface/ and note that the critique applies to Moodle as well. The main thrust of the critique is that when you reply to a post in a discussion thread, you only see the text of the post you are replying to. However, one often wants to refer to other posts in the thread. To do this currently, one needs to right click and open up another window and suchlike contortions. I think that a good way to address this issue would be to initially just show the text of post you are replying to together with titles of other posts in the thread. There should be checkboxes next to these titles and a button to refresh the view, showing the text of all the other posts whose checkboxes have been checked on. Or some +/- controls which allow you to expand the titles to complete posts.
Comments associated with the post: 
Comment 1: I agree with this 100% Zig. I hope Mike Churchward will see this suggestion, as I am sure he is the guy that can give us these features in the future.
Comment 2: Hi Zig, This is a complex issue. I am replying after Bryan and I do see the title if his post. But having all post in a thread open would suppose lot of scrolling. And opening/closing individual messages, quite a mess, more if you are in a slow connection. What do you think about a "compose page" in an small pop-up window? In such way you can keep the whole thread open in a window and the answer in other in a "natural" way, without having to right click, etc. I understand that threading usually means branching and see the risk of fragmentation that Feldstein points out. But I think he is talking about "casual" or "general purpose" forum conversations. Where all contribute to all. But in some parts of education we do need branching, and been able to review arguments in the thread, why branching occurs etc. Moodle offers a "flat" format, but I use most the "nested", since I do see al posts (with scrolling) AND the tree. What I try to do (and not always do) is to reply to the OP if my answer is a kind of summing-up or combined reply for several posts (something quite usual if you have a teacher role). But there seem to be no netiquette agreement on this nowadays (young people have not used usenet newsgroups at all). I would like the "reply to conversation" button suggested by Feldstein. And I am sure it is much more easy to implement. Perhaps the mere existence of the choice (to all, to poster) would enforce thinking about before posting.
Comment 3: Isn't it meant to have two answer buttons: answer discussion and answer previous post? with the first button you get the discussionstart to answer and with the second button you get the post you've clicked in. Now already you have a link to view the discussion start message in Moodle when answering a message
Comment 4: Enrique, agreed this is a complex issue. However, I think Feldsteins suggestion of making branch or "tangent" posts new discussions is a good idea. A flat view of the original post, along with a view showing tangents allows for the creative flow that often emerges in real conversation, yet maintains the integrity of the original discussion. The threaded model can and very often does lead to a disintegration of the original subject when ambiguity and neediness creeps in. It can be difficult to keep on track with the original thread when branches that may not be relevent to the topic are all displayed with those that are. This isn't very intuitive.Â  At the same time relevant information often comes from tangent branches, so it might be nice to somehow merge just that kernel of relevence from tangent branches into the original discusssion. In that sense, I might suggest an "integrate tangent" link to go along with Feldsteins "start tangent" link.
Comment 5: I think there's a number of issues that are being dealt with here. One is conversational flow and the dispaly thereof. And the second is tagging posts with additional information (meta-tagging?). What I'm playing with now is how to set up forums so that there can be different sets of tagging available. As an example, a bug tracker would allow for tagging of a discussion as a whole - where the problem is, what type it is - and then tagging of posts - additional information, potential fix. A question and answer forum might want posts to be tagged as question, further info, response. Getting this information hooked into the posts properly, along with linking the relationships, will allow us to start designing the informational display and the user interface. I could see a forum format the collapses the posts like gmail, and allows me to quickly open and close them while I'm editing. It would be great to have a personal scrapbook, that allows me to collect bits of information as I move through forums and other activities . These scraps would have appropriate informational ties back to their sources and would allow me to drop them into posts or other activities. Anyway, lots of thinking still to do...
Comment 6: In the 80s we had a simple version of cMap: you could attach notes to other posts on a graphical screen or connect two other notes: notes were visualised as bulbs the more refences, the bigger the bulb (the core statement?) you could follow a thread and attach a new node but also connect two other statements (kind of harvesting, new in forums!) (several notes could be grouped in a super bulb? with a lable as a kind of summary) So, a cMap as forum-metaphor? Before I push the answer button,Â I read a thread, so what is the problem? The only problem I have with current Moodle forums, is that you loose the view on the branch where the reply is aiming at: like this message is an answer on the first message in this forum.... maybe should an answer be right under the previous answer, unless you press a (new)button called "new branch" which will be a new column next to the previous one. maybe something like the swimlanes in UML? maybe a merge button for two branches is also wishable?

Post description: Hallo everybody, as promised I implemented two new features for Moodle within the scope of my diploma thesis. 1. A new forumtype: Metaforum A metaforum is now an additional forumtype. Metaforums offer a view on chosen forums of the same course and don't contain posts themselves. This forumtype should be helpfull to keep track of new posts etc. if a lot of forums exist in one course. Metaforums can be used to give a summarized overview of chosen forums. 2. Enhanced linking between forums and resources Generally spoken this is a possibility to allocated discussions to resources of the same course. To admit this resources can now optionally be allocated to forums. If such allocations have been made, discussions in forums can be allocated to one of the resources allocated to the forum. If an allocation has been made while viewing a resource a link to add a new discussion allocated to the resource viewed is displayed. If discussions have already been allocated a link to an overview of all allocated discussions is displayed too. I would be glad about testers and comments on the new features. These then get stored as simple ascii but translated back to the correct character by the browser when displayed as HTML. Safari (and possibly Opera) simply substitute a question mark for characters outside the specified encoding. Neither is actually 'correct', in fact the Mozilla way, while more useful for my purposes, may actually be less correct from a standards point of view. ref:

Comment 1: Hi Alan, This is probably the easiest way, and there's currently no way to automate this or do anything more fancy. When you create groups I always recommend that you create them in a Grouping . A Grouping is a logical collection of groups.Â  When you set up your forum, and you put it into Separate Groups mode, you can set a Grouping. The effect of that Grouping is that the activity is only limited to those groups, and ignores any other group in the course. This means that your students will only see that one group, and will not be prompted to choose a group when posting. As I say, I always advise creating groups in a grouping. In fact I would advise that all groups are in at least one grouping. Hope this helps, Andrew

Post title: 'Mail now' does not immediately sent notifications to forum subscribers
Post description: Hello, We have an issue that we have been looking into for a while now but unfortunately are not able to find the exact place to make the appropriate changes. When ticking the box 'mail now' at the bottom of a forum message, the mail notifications to the forum subscribers is not immediately sent out. That message appears to go out with any other notifications. We are looking into cron-job settings, but that seems to affect quite a bit of other actions (see list below) Does anyone have an idea where to change the settings to make the 'mail now' function work appropriately? Thanks, Julian Cron -job execution order: -
Cleanup old sessions -
Send new user passwords -
Send failed login notifications -
Legacy cron processing for plugins -
Background processing for gradebook -
Background processing for events -
Calculate completion data -
Background processing for portfolio plugins -
Background processing for plagiarism plugins -
Send calendar notifications -
Sync external blogs -
Background processing for question engine -
Forum mailings and maintenance jobs
Comments associated with the post: 
Comment 1: I think that "mail now" is a bit of misnomer... As far as I know, this means that instead of respecting the forum-specific delay for mailing a given post, it is added to the mail queue right away. The mail queue will be processed at the next cron run, whenever that occurs. That means that there can still be a delay until the mail actually goes out. For example, if your forum is set to allow editing of posts for 20 mins and cron runs every 5 mins, "mail now" means that your mail will go out within 5 mins instead of within 25 mins. Caveat: there were some substantial changes with regards to cron in the recent versions of Moodle, which may affect this, but probably not or not significantly. If the understanding is not the issue, there may be a technical problem with the scheduling of mail-now mails on your site. There have been a few threads about different technical issues. Search the forum.

Post title: Forum not sorted by date
Post description: I thought that forums were automatically sorted by the date of the last posting. Â I now have a forum where recent postings are not appearing at the top. Â Does anyone know if this is a setting or if it might be a bug? thanks in advance. Brian
Comments associated with the post: 
Comment 1: Hi Brian, The default view of a forum in Moodle is to "Display replies in nested form." This means that the newest replies are generally at the bottom in order of receipt based on the reply. So each direct reply to a post is nested beneath the original post with the newest at the bottom. If you want to see the newest posts at the top then you need to go to the top of the forum page and select "Display replies flat, with newest first" from the drop down list. Hope this helps.

Post title: Forum Development for 2.8.  Any news?
Post description: Just curious, if there is any progress on a way ahead for forum development. Both ForumNG and Advanced forums seem to have been rejected for inclusion in core (eg https://tracker.moodle.org/browse/MDL-21538 ) and some work is proceeding on developing the existing forum in one popular issue, the per discussion subscription (see https://tracker.moodle.org/browse/MDL-1626 ) Some of the old entries in the roadmap relevant to forum have gone, with one small comment remaining. http://docs.moodle.org/dev/Roadmap#Current_work -Derek
Comments associated with the post: 
Comment 1: Bump. Probably a dumb idea to post this on a Sunday. -Derek
Comment 2: Hi Derek, Thank you for raising this in the forums. During our planning period, we started to scope out the various changes required within the forums and the amount of work required for each. Unfortunately when we looked at both ForumNG (mod_forumng), and Advanced forums (mod_hsuforum), we felt that they were not quite the right fit for Moodle. This was in part because we felt that some of the features included in these solutions did not fit outside of the specific requirements for which they were written for. As an example, both solutions include an anonymity feature, but implement them differently. mod_forumng only allows tutors to post anonymously, whilst mod_hsuforum only allows all users to post under the name 'Anonymous'. Both were written for the HE market, but clearly there are major differences in the perceived requirements. Neither of these implementations allowed for use-cases such as role-playing which are an important pedagogical tool. In any case, if we had decided to migrate to either mod_forumng, or mod_hsuforum, we would have needed to either rewrite within the existing mod_forum plugin, or to provide an upgrade path from mod_forum to the chosen module. In migrating from mod_assignment to mod_assign we learnt many lessons about renaming modules and refactors of this kind... although this was largely a successful migration, it took us many releases to get things into the right state to be able to finally remove the old module. Instead, we have opted to look at each feature in turn and look to improve the existing forum to add the desired functionality. The aim is to improve the forum for the largest number of users and support as many pedagogical approaches as possible. The encompassing issue for all of the forum changes that we've been looking at is MDL-39707 . MDL-1626 is one of the components of this overarching issue and is one of the most requested features of all time within Moodle. I'm hoping that the feature will be integrated this afternoon and will be rolled in weeklies on Thursday. The next forum-related task we aim to look at is likely to be the layout and UI refactor ( MDL-41773 ) with the key aims of this task being to make the user interface more accessible, and clearer. It's likely that this will incorporate a couple of the other issues (e.g. MDL-8501 , and MDL-33692 ). I can't give a timescale on these, but the intention is to have these in place for the Moodle 2.8 release. With regards the roadmap, Martin updated the roadmap recently to give more consistency and to list each project that we are working on. Hope that this helps, Andrew

At a cursory glance you have all the issues I think are generally regarded as important here: edit in place, private reply, accessibility , reporting, anon posts, role playing (I'd love to be able to do De Bono's hats!!) etc. As to the roadmap. Post title: Q&A Forum Instructions
Post description: Hello, I work at the University of Illinois to create Moodle courses for our instructors and help them understand how to use Moodle. Many of our instructors had questions on how to set up a Q&A Forum on Moodle 1.9.9. When we directed our instructors to moodle.org for help, they still had questions on how to set it up. I want to get your opinion. I posted the instructions that we came up with below. Are these instructions helpful? Is there anywhere else we could direct the instructors for help? Thanks! Q and A Forum Help Article The Q and A Forum is a great instructional tool for instructors to require students to respond to a question or prompt before reading what their peers think. This kind of activity works well to foster original thinking while reducing the âme tooâ posts that can be common in discussion forums. Unfortunately, the default settings for the Q and A Forum need to be modified for it to function as intended. In most cases when using a Q and A Forum, an instructor should be the only user starting new threads (discussion topics). Students will then respond to the instructorâs threads and then they will be able to view and respond to their peersâ posts. When setting up a Q and A Forum, instructors should not include the discussion questions, and/or prompts to which your students should respond in the Forum introduction. The Forum introduction is the place to inform students that they should respond to each of the discussion threads first before being able to view and respond their peersâ posts. The threads posted by the instructor should be the discussion questions and/or prompts to which the students should respond. A Q and A Forum should always have at least one thread started by the instructor before students access it. To configure the Q and A Forum to work as described above, make the following changes: Create a Q and A Forum and add a general Forum Introduction. Access the Override permissions tab. Select the Student role. Set the Start new discussions permission to prevent. Save the changes. Save the forum. Add a new question or prompt for your students to reply to before seeing their peersâ responses. Add as many new questions or prompts as desired for this Q and A Forum activity.

Post title: How do I stop emails sent to students each time a forum is posted?
Post description: I have created a forum in my course and have invited students to post their views on certain topics.Â  Each time a student post something on the forum, an email will be sent to all students.Â  How do I stop emails being sent.Â  I just wanted the students to participate in a discussion and it can be very exasperating that sometimes all students will be receiving emails containg thread of replies? Many thanks Frankie Yee
Comments associated with the post: 
Comment 1: Frankie - I'm assuming you are using Moodle 1.8; however, the same holds for Moodle 1.9. Generally speaking, the user can determine whether or not he/she wishes to be subscribed to a forum. If they are subscribed then they will receive the emails; however, if they unsubscribe from the forum the user will not receive the emails. The teacher can force subscription or allow the users to choose. When forced all students are enrolled; however, even in this case if a user disables his/her email address then emails will not be sent to them. If the teacher allows the individual to choose, then it is up to the student. The teacher can also go in and unsubscribe students from a forum if they wish to stop students being notified. Another option is to not allow subscriptions. You can also set the subscriptions not allowed option to the Force everyone to be subscribed? setting when creating or updating a forum. Peace - Anthony
Comment 2: Thanks Anthony.Â  This is really helpful. Frankie Yee
Comment 3: @Frankie: I agree with everything Anthony suggests. Another option to make the forum email notifications more manageable for your students (or fellow teachers) is... -user visits their user profile -select 'Edit' tab -select 'Show Advanced' button to expand all fields in first section of user profile page -for 'Email digest type' field, select option that reads 'Subjects (daily email with subjects only)'. This setting will result in a single daily digest email with subjects only being sent to users subscribed to the forum(s) concerned. If there is no forum posts in a given day, no email notification is sent. Personally, i like this option because it allows users to stay informed without necessarily having to visit 'my moodle' page, the course or forum to check for new posts. Cheers, Chad

Comment 9: We identified a resolution for our forum email problem.Â  Here was our scenario and the fix in case this helps others. Scenario: Our course has multiple forums (one per week).Â  We found that some students were getting emails for some forums, but not everyone was getting emails.Â  When we investigated further, it became clear that students received emails for forums to which they had previously posted and not to forums to which they had not yet posted. This was due to the combination of these settings: Student profiles included this setting for Forum auto-subscribe: âYes, when I post, subscribe me to that forumâ. Each of the forums in the course was set to âAllow everyone to choose to subscribeâ. The combination of these settings resulted in students getting emails for forums only if they have posted to the forum already. To fix this, we did the following: Force subscribed everyone in the class to every forum. De-enrolled all of the students. Re-enrolled all of the students. The force subscription then took effect. Hope this helps!

Post title: Messages from Moodle rejected by email provider
Post description: We are using v. 2.6 i don't know if this is a Moodle issue or email. This issue has been occurring since summer, which is about the time we upgraded. Forum posts sent as emails from Moodle are being rejected by email providers - Yahoo, AOL, gMail. Each message says something about the message being rejected due to a policy issue. This is part of the message from gMail: Our
system has detected that this message is 550-5.7.1 likely unsolicited mail. Is there a way to change a setting in Moodle to make the messages not look like spam ? Or what do I tell my users to change on their end?
Comments associated with the post: 
Comment 1: Hi Sue Is this for receiver's not on 'digest' but get an email for every post? I think what they do is note that the sender's domain is not where it's coming from, eg, a moodle.com site is sending a @gmail.com email - they don't match. Try going to the Forum settings (Site Admin / Plugins/ Activity Modules / Forum) and untick 'use email address in reply.
Comment 2: Hi Sue - we encountered this issue last year (2014). It was a change in policy by Yahoo that triggered the rejections from all providers. It is because Moodle issues emails using the student's email address, and in the case of Yahoo they are flagging any emails not generated from their servers as being a security risk. Read: http://www.pcworld.com/article/2141120/yahoo-email-antispoofing-policy-breaks-mailing-lists.html for an explanation. In our case, instead of using Meg's solution, we have changed our provisioning to substitute any user's yahoo email address to our college provided Office 365 address and send them an email at their yahoo address to explain the switch. We opted to do this rather than prevent Moodle using student email addresses as our lecturers find it very useful to be able to reply to emails and have them go straight back to the student. If you prevent moodle using the student's email address it gets substituted with a 'Do not reply' address that obv. can't be replied to. Hope this helps.

Post title: one forum for three courses????
Post description: Is there a way to create one forum that can be used by students from three different courses?
Comments associated with the post: 
Comment 1: Chris, a Meta Course may be your best bet. The Parent course is the Meta Course, and the Child Courses can be "enrolled" into the Meta course. The students are automatically added to the Meta course since they are already in the Child Courses. Doug
Comment 2: Thanks, but how do I accomplish this?
Comment 3: You need to get your administrator for Moodle to create a Meta Course with you as the teacher, and then add the courses in. Then you click on the Child Tab under the Admin block. Since I am admin for our server , I'm not sure if you can see the tab or you may have to get your Moodle admin to do it. Then you add the courses. Doug
Comment 4: Hi Chris and Doug, The admin (or anyone with course creation privileges) should create a new course. In the course settings, set Is this a meta course = Yes. Don't assign a Teacher. Then click the Course administration block -> Child courses link and select the three courses that you want to be children of the metacourse. Put the forum in the metacourse. Here's another discussion almost identical to this one.
Comment 5: Once you have the Metacourse created, you will need to setup the forum. If you want a single discussion forum for the members of all three child courses to have access, I would recommend that the metacourse be setup as a social format. To do that someone (the admin or a course creator) will need to go into the meta course and click on settings in the administrator toolbar. For "format" select "social format." Now this metacourse has become a discussion forum that anyone in the subscribed courses (child courses) will have access to. If you need multiple lines of discussion in this course I would set it up similar to the way this "Using Moodle" classroom is setup - "Topics Format" with as many topics and forums as you need. Good luck. If you get a chance, let us know what you ended up doing and how it turned out.

Post title: Forum email and reply-to address
Post description: Hi, Could someone explain how Moodle applies the reply-to email address to outgoing forum emails? Our Moodle site is configured with a standard 'no-reply' address and it is correctly applied to the 'From:' field when sending email from forums. We have updated the way in which the no-reply address is used in order to satisfy mail relay recommendations and reduce the possibility of Moodle notifications being detected as spam . Best wishes, Andrew

Post title: Forum: send e-mail to groups only
Post description: Hi there I'm running Moodle 3.3, so that's a heads up. Here's my situation; we have one course we use where all our staff members are enrolled. We have a few separate catagories with forums that only a few groups of our staff use (for example a catagory French for the teachers who teach French). The problem is that I have to manually enroll all users to all different forums, because I don't want to subscribe all users to all forums in that category. I tried making groups in the course, and setting the activity to that group only but everyone is still listed in the e-mail listing and will probably receive an e-mail (even though they don't have access to the forum. I'd rather not create a course for the communication of each type of communication group, so... I came here for advice. In short: is there a way to make a group subscribe to a forum? I'd install a plugin to sync that group to a site cohort too. Thanks in advance!
Comments associated with the post: 
Comment 1: Hi Bruno, This is actually very easy to implement. At the moment you have created groups for each of the study groups, and presumably placed users within these groups. When you create your forum, just set the Group Mode (in Common Module Settings) to "Separate Groups". I would recommend that you also create a Grouping of your various groups, which you can then select at the same time as the group mode. Groupings are designed to bring together a collection of related groups to be used in an activity. For example, you might have a piece of group work where your students are expected to work together as a team and submit a brief of their work. They may want to discuss that work in a forum, and then several weeks later they submit the final product in an assignment . To do so, you can create 5 groups for your students for this activity. You would create a single grouping containing all five of these groups. You can then select this Grouping (of groups) when setting up the assignments and forums for your group work. Later on, you place students in a different set of groups for a new piece of group work. You would create your new groups, and new grouping for this. If you had not created and used the groupings, both activities would see every group in the course, which can quickly become confusing to students. Andrew

Sometimes a better way is In each course that should be counted, turn on completion tracking and set a completion criterion For each credential that is composed of multiple courses, create a course to hold the overview, turn on completion tracking, and add completion criteria including completion of each pre-requisite course. Execute scheduled task: Incoming email pickup

Comments associated with the post: 
Comment 1: Hi Corey, So it looks like you've got past the first few hurdles that some are facing (sub-address formatting is often not enabled on some MTAs). So that's a good start. These fail codes come fromÂ lib/classes/message/inbound/address_manager.php and are a bitwise addition of a number of fail codes. In this case, you have a failcode of 10, which is a bitwise addition of: const VALIDATION_UNKNOWN_HANDLER = 2; and const VALIDATION_UNKNOWN_DATAKEY = 8; This is a bit of an unusual one. Essentially it looks like the address was generated, but before it was used, something changed about your system - maybe you reset and repeated an upgrade on your test site? Andrew
Comment 2: Hi Andrew, Many thanks for the reply. Apologies in the delay in replying to you, I've been caught up with other tasks. Comment 3: Hi Corey, The first thing that jumps out is lack of case-sensitivity on the local-part of the reply-to address. You'll notice that the student01 message has an address with localpart: moodleadmin+AAAAAAAAAAIAAAAAAAAAaAAAAAAAAAACVAqOB2WW3Mz0ckPf whilst the message received in your moodleadmin file is: moodleadmin+aaaaaaaaaaiaaaaaaaaaaaaaaaaaaaacvaqob2ww3mz0ckpf Since these messages are base64 decoded, the case does convey different meaning. According to RFC-5321, 
```text
The local-part of a mailbox MUST BE treated as case sensitive.
Therefore, 
SMTP
 implementations MUST take care to preserve the case of mailbox local-parts.
```
 I'd say that this would be the first thing to double-check. Andrew
Comment 4: Hi Andrew, Many thanks for your continued support. The webmail application that I was using my development virtual machine was called RainLoop . In the meantime I've switched to Roundcube , and I can confirm that everything is working as expected. The issue that I had was caused by the email address being transformed to lowercase. I'll continue my investigations and hopefully have a patch soon for t his MDL-50811 tracker item ,Â which started me down this path. With thanks. -Corey
